titleStmt.author: Pope, Alexander, 1688-1744.

notesStmt.note: Verse - "How much, egregious Moore, are we".

body.head: To the Ingenious Mr. MOORE, Author of the Celebrated WORM-POWDER.

lg.l: HOW much, Egregious MOORE, are we
Whate'er we think, whate'er we see,
Man, is a very Worm by Birth,
A-while he crawls upon the Earth,
That Woman is a Worm we find,
She first convers'd with her own kind,
But whether Man, or He, God knows,
With that pure Stuff from whence we rose,
The Learn'd themselves, we Book-Worms name;
The Nymph, whose Tail is all on Flame,
First from a Worm they took their Rise,
That Statesmen have a Worm is seen
Their Conscience is a Worm within,
That gnaws them Night and Day.
Ah! MOORE! thy Skill were well Employ'd,
If thou could'st make the Courtier void
Vain is thy Art, thy Powder Vain,
Since Worms shall Eat ev'n Thee.
Thou only can'st our Fates adjourn,
Some few short Years, no more;
Ev'n BUTTON's Wits to Worms shall turn,

div.p: LONDON: Printed for E. Curll at the Dial and Bible against St. Dunstan's Church in Fleetstreet. Price Two Pence. Where may be had, Mr. POPE's Court Poems. Price Six Pence. 1716.
N. B. Speedily will be Publish'd, some more of Mr. POPE's Pieces, and all his Writings for the Future, except HOMER, will be Printed for E. Curll.
